q: Can flood barriers be used on historic homes?
a: Yes—reversible installations that avoid altering the original façade are preferred. Clamp-frame panels preserve masonry and meet preservation-board standards. See building-code standards.

q: Do I need approval from a preservation board?
a: Usually yes. Submit color renderings, anchor details, and a reversibility statement. We prepare drawings for local review.

q: How can barriers blend with period architecture?
a: Color-matched powder coating and concealed anchors maintain visual integrity. Review powder-coating options.

q: Are there limits on drilling or anchoring?
a: Yes—anchors must avoid decorative stone or brick edges. Compression-mounted frames are non-invasive alternatives.

q: Can heritage materials be protected from water intrusion?
a: Yes—barriers paired with interior sump pumps keep wood floors and plaster dry while maintaining the original exterior.
